lines.content: I am a bot that helps you organise your tasks and boost your productivity so that you can focus on the more important things in life, such as watching your favourite TV show. I can:
- Able to read your text inputs.
- Execute commands to help you keep your tasks organised.
- Keep it saved locally once you leave the program.
All you need to do is to [download](https://github.com/rahhulleee/ip) me and run the `Launcher.java` file! :shit: And your life will become so much __*more organised*__.
3. No more missing outings with your friends
**Ensure you have Java 11 or above installed in your Computer.**
Returns a list of tasks in the order when the task was added.
Returns a list of tasks in the order when the task was added matching a given key.
Here are the matching tasks in your list!:
Marks the task at index to be completed.
Nice! I've marked this task as done:
Unmarks the task at index to be completed.
Ok, I've marked this task as not done yet:
Now you have 0 tasks in this list!
Adds a todo task with its name as the parameter.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 2 tasks in this list.
Adds a deadline task with its name and deadline (date) as the parameter.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 3 tasks in this list!
Adds a event task with its name, from (start datetime) and to (end datetime) as the parameter.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 4 tasks in this list!
Please input all time in 24hrs format and date in YYYY-MM-DD.
Here are the list of commands and formats:
#### How do I add a task to the list?
To add a task, you can use the following commands:
#### How do I mark a task as completed?
To mark a task as completed, use the `mark <index>` command followed by the index of the task you want to mark.
#### How do I delete a task from the list?
To delete a task from the list, use the `delete <index>` command followed by the index of the task you want to delete.
#### How do I search for tasks containing a specific keyword?
To search for tasks containing a specific keyword, use the `find <keyword>` command followed by the keyword you want to search for.
#### How do I exit the program?
To exit the program, simply type `bye` and press Enter.
| `find <key>`      | Lists all tasks matching given key.            | `find homework`                         |
| `mark <index>`    | Marks the task at index to be completed.      | `mark 1`                                |
| `unmark <index>`  | Marks the task at index to be not completed.  | `unmark 1`                              |
| `todo <name>`     | Adds a todo task with its name.               | `todo homework`                         |
| `deadline <name> /by <date> <time>` | Adds a deadline task with name and date in `yyyy-mm-dd` format. | `deadline homework /by 2024-02-01 1900` |
| `event <name> /from <date> <time> /to <date> <time>` | Adds an event task with name and date in `yyyy-mm-dd` format. | `event career fair /from 2024-01-01 1900 /to 2024-01-02 1000` |

I am a bot that helps you organise your tasks and boost your productivity so that you can focus on the more important things in life, such as watching your favourite TV show. I can:
- Able to read your text inputs.
- Execute commands to help you keep your tasks organised.
- Keep it saved locally once you leave the program.
All you need to do is to [download](https://github.com/rahhulleee/ip) me and run the `Launcher.java` file! :shit: And your life will become so much __*more organised*__.
3. No more missing outings with your friends
**Ensure you have Java 11 or above installed in your Computer.**

Here are the list of commands and formats:
#### How do I add a task to the list?
To add a task, you can use the following commands:
#### How do I mark a task as completed?
To mark a task as completed, use the `mark <index>` command followed by the index of the task you want to mark.
#### How do I delete a task from the list?
To delete a task from the list, use the `delete <index>` command followed by the index of the task you want to delete.
#### How do I search for tasks containing a specific keyword?
To search for tasks containing a specific keyword, use the `find <keyword>` command followed by the keyword you want to search for.
#### How do I exit the program?
To exit the program, simply type `bye` and press Enter.
| `find <key>`      | Lists all tasks matching given key.            | `find homework`                         |
| `mark <index>`    | Marks the task at index to be completed.      | `mark 1`                                |
| `unmark <index>`  | Marks the task at index to be not completed.  | `unmark 1`                              |
| `todo <name>`     | Adds a todo task with its name.               | `todo homework`                         |
| `deadline <name> /by <date> <time>` | Adds a deadline task with name and date in `yyyy-mm-dd` format. | `deadline homework /by 2024-02-01 1900` |
| `event <name> /from <date> <time> /to <date> <time>` | Adds an event task with name and date in `yyyy-mm-dd` format. | `event career fair /from 2024-01-01 1900 /to 2024-01-02 1000` |
* Facilitates adding tasks to the Duke application's storage.
* This class represents an action to add a new task into the storage system of the Duke application.
* It holds a reference to the storage where the task needs to be added and the task itself.
* After adding a task, the class can also provide a string representation of the addition to be used
* for output in the Parser class, indicating the successful addition of the task and the total number
* Constructs an {@code AddTask} action with specified storage and task.
* This constructor initializes the {@code AddTask} object with the storage system where the task will be added
* and the task to be added. The {@code storage} is used to access and modify the list of tasks, while the {@code t}
* represents the specific task to add.
* @param storage The storage system of the Duke application where the task will be added. It must be initialized
* @param t       The task to be added to the storage system. This task should not be {@code null}.
* Adds a task to the storage's list of tasks.
* This method accesses the storage to retrieve the current list of tasks and appends the task represented by
* the {@code t} instance variable to this list.
* Provides a string representation of the task addition action.
* This method generates a message indicating that a task has been successfully added to the storage. It also
* displays the added task and the total number of tasks in the storage. This string representation is useful for
* providing feedback to the user about the result of their action.
* @return A string detailing the task that was added, along with the current total number of tasks in the storage.
String temp = "Got it. I've added this task: \n";
temp += "\nNow you have " + this.storage.load().size() + " tasks in the list.";
* Handles the deletion of tasks from the Duke application's storage based on their index.
* This class encapsulates the functionality required to delete a task from the storage's list of tasks.
* It is constructed with a reference to the storage and the index of the task to be deleted. The deletion
* process involves removing the task from the storage's task list and storing the deleted task's string
* representation for feedback purposes. The {@code toString} method provides a message that includes the
* details of the deleted task and the updated total number of tasks in storage.
* Creates a {@code DeleteTask} action with specified storage and the index of the task to be deleted.
* This constructor initializes a {@code DeleteTask} object with a reference to the storage system from where
* the task will be deleted and the index of the task in the list. It is important to note that the index
* should be based on user-visible numbering (typically starting from 1) which will be adjusted internally
* to match the zero-based indexing of Java collections. The task's string representation is initially empty
* and will be populated upon deletion.
* @param storage The storage system of the Duke application from which the task will be deleted.
* @param index   The index of the task to be deleted, as seen by the user, starting from 1.
* Deletes a task from the storage's list of tasks based on its index.
* This method removes the task at the specified index from the storage's ArrayList of tasks.
* The index is adjusted to account for list indexing starting at 0. Before removal, the task's
* string representation is stored in {@code this.task} to allow for reporting what was deleted.
* Returns a string representation of the task deletion action.
* After a task is deleted, this method generates a confirmation message including the details of the deleted task
* and the updated total number of tasks remaining in storage. This feedback is essential for informing the user
* about the outcome of their delete command, ensuring clarity in the application's state changes.
* @return A string message detailing the task that was removed and the current total number of tasks in storage.
String temp = "Noted. I've removed this task: \n";
temp += "\nNow you have " + storage.load().size() + " tasks in this list.";
* A class representing the action of finding tasks in a task management application.
* Searches for tasks based on a specified keyword and provides a list of matching tasks.
* Constructs a FindTask object with the given storage and task keyword.
* @param storage The Storage object responsible for loading tasks.
* @param task    A String representing the keyword to search for in tasks.
* Fills the list of tasks with tasks that match the specified keyword.
* Returns a formatted String representation of the matching tasks.
* @return A String displaying the matching tasks or an apology if none are found.
return "Sorry :( ! There are no such tasks.";
StringBuilder result = new StringBuilder("Here are the matching tasks on your list!: \n");
* Provides functionality to list all tasks currently stored in the Duke application's storage.
* This class is designed to access the application's storage system and retrieve a formatted list
* of all tasks. Each task is presented alongside its index in the storage list, offering a clear
* overview of all tasks to the user. In case the storage list is empty, the class will return a
* simple message indicating that no tasks are available. This functionality supports the user's
* ability to view all their tasks at a glance.
* Generates a string representation of all tasks in the storage's task list.
* This method iterates through the ArrayList of tasks in the storage, appending each task's
* string representation to the result string, prefixed by its list index. If the list is empty,
* it returns a message indicating that the list is empty.
* @return A string listing all tasks with their index in the list, or a message if the list is empty.
* Enables marking of tasks as completed within the Duke application's storage system.
* This class is tasked with identifying a specific task by its index and updating its status to reflect completion.
* Constructed with references to the storage system and the target task's index, it facilitates the marking process,
* ensuring that the designated task is accurately flagged as done. The operation is confirmed through a message
* detailing the task's new status, providing immediate feedback to the user on the successful update.
* Constructs a {@code MarkTask} action with specified storage and the index of the task to be marked as completed.
* This constructor initializes a {@code MarkTask} object with a reference to the storage
* system where the tasks are managed and the index of the task that
* needs to be marked as done. The index provided should correspond to the position of the task
* in the user-visible list, which is then adjusted internally to accommodate zero-based indexing used in storage.
* @param storage The storage system of the Duke application, responsible for managing tasks.
* @param index   The 1-based index of the task to be marked as completed, as viewed by the user.
* Marks a task as done based on its index in the task list.
* This method updates the status of a specified task to "completed" and generates a confirmation message.
* It retrieves the task by its index (adjusted for zero-based indexing) from the storage's list of tasks,
* marks the task as done, and returns a message indicating the task has been successfully marked.
* @return A string message confirming the task has been marked as done, along with the task's details.
String temp = "Nice! I've marked this task as done: \n";
* Manages the unmarking of tasks within the Duke application, setting them as not completed.
* This class provides the functionality to change the status of a specific task from "completed" to "not completed"
* based on its index in the task list. It is instantiated with a reference to the storage where tasks are maintained
* and the index of the task to be updated. This action is part of the application's task management capabilities,
* allowing users to dynamically adjust task statuses as needed.
* Constructs a new UnmarkTask object to manage the unmarking of tasks within the Duke application.
* This constructor initializes an instance of the UnmarkTask class with references to the storage where tasks
* are maintained and the index of the task to be updated. It is used to instantiate objects that provide the
* functionality to change the status of a specific task from "completed" to "not completed" based on its index in
* the task list. This action is part of the application's task management capabilities, allowing users to
* dynamically adjust task statuses as needed.
* @param storage The storage instance where tasks are maintained.
* @param index   The index of the task to be updated within the task list.
* Marks the specified task as not done based on its index attribute.
* This method accesses the task identified by the given index in the storage's task list and updates its status to
* "not done." It constructs and returns a confirmation message that includes the task's details, indicating to the
* user that the task status has been successfully updated.
* @return A string message confirming the task has been marked as not done, along with the task's details.
String temp = "OK, I've marked this task as not done yet: \n";
* The DukeException class represents a custom exception specific to the Duke application.
* This exception is used to handle errors and exceptional situations within the Duke application. It extends
* the standard Java Exception class and is designed to provide a mechanism for capturing and handling
* application-specific issues that may arise during the execution of Duke's functionalities.
* Constructs a new DukeException with the specified error message.
* This constructor is used to create instances of DukeException with a custom error message that describes
* the nature of the exception. It allows for informative and user-friendly messages to be associated with
* instances of this exception, aiding in the identification and resolution of issues within the Duke application.
* @param message The error message associated with the exception.
* The Parser class is responsible for interpreting user input and executing corresponding task operations.
* It serves as the intermediary between the user interface and the application's logic, parsing the input
* commands to perform actions such as adding, listing, marking, unmarking, deleting tasks, and handling
* task-related exceptions. The class supports a variety of commands, including "todo", "deadline", "event",
* "mark", "unmark", and "delete", each requiring specific input formats and handling potential input errors
* Upon receiving input, the Parser decodes the command, validates it, and then initiates the appropriate action
* by creating instances of action classes like AddTask, DeleteTask, ListTask, MarkTask, and UnmarkTask, or directly
* manipulating tasks through the storage class. It also provides feedback or error messages based on the outcomes
* of operations or the nature of exceptions encountered.

* Represents a dialog box in the chat interface of a chatbot application.
* This class is responsible for creating a dialog box containing a message
* and an associated image. Dialog boxes can be customized for different speakers
* in the chat, such as the user or the chatbot itself.
* Constructs a DialogBox with specified text and image.
* The DialogBox aligns its content to the top right by default and applies
* predefined padding and spacing for aesthetic spacing.

* @param iv The ImageView containing the image to be displayed alongside the text.
displayPicture.setFitHeight(100.0); // Consider removing setFitWidth for aspect ratio preservation

* The dialog box is flipped, placing the image on the left and text on the right,

* @param iv The ImageView containing Duke's image.
* @return A DialogBox instance configured for Duke's dialog, with flipped alignment.
public static DialogBox getDukeDialog(Label l, ImageView iv) {
* Main application class for Duke, a JavaFX application that facilitates interactive chat.
* Duke is a GUI-based chatbot that allows users to interact with the application through
* a graphical interface. It supports adding, deleting, and listing tasks, among other functionalities.
* This class sets up the primary stage and scene for the application, initializing the chat interface.
* Starts the main application stage, setting up the layout, scene, and event handlers.
* This method initializes the graphical user interface, including input fields, buttons,

* This method ensures that when the user interacts with the input controls, the appropriate
* actions are taken to process and respond to the input.
* Displays a welcome message to the user upon application start.
* This method is called during the initialization phase to greet the user.
Output output = new Output(new Parser(new Storage()), new Storage());

* A class representing a Deadlines task, a type of Task in a task management application.

* An abstract class representing a generic Task in a task management application.
* All specific task types should extend this class.
* Provides basic functionality for task manipulation such as marking and retrieving deadlines.
* Constructs a Task with the given description.
* The task is initially isMarked as not completed.
* @param description A String describing the task.
* Checks if the task is isMarked as completed.
* @return true if the task is isMarked as completed, false otherwise.
* Returns a String representation of the task.
* Abstract method to be implemented by subclasses.
* Returns a String identifier specific to the type of task.
* @return A String identifier for the task type.
* Abstract method to be implemented by subclasses.
* Returns the deadline of the task.
* @return LocalDate representing the deadline of the task.
* A class that represents a ToDo task, a type of Task in a task management application.
* Constructs a ToDo task with the given description.
* @param description A String describing the ToDo task.
* Returns a String representation of the ToDo task, indicating its completion status.
* @return A formatted String indicating the completion status and description of the ToDo task.
* Returns a String identifier for the ToDo task.
* @return A String identifier specific to ToDo tasks.
* Returns the deadline of the ToDo task.
* Since ToDo tasks do not have deadlines, it returns the current date.
* Represents the output interface for the Duke application.
* This class handles the presentation of information to the user.
* The ASCII art representation of the Duke logo.
* Constructs an Output object with the specified Parser and Storage.
* @param parser The Parser object used for processing user input.
* @param storage The Storage object used for managing data storage.
* Creates a decorative layer around the provided string for better visual separation.
* @param s The string to be encapsulated within the decorative layer.
* @return A string with a decorative layer around the provided input.
* Generates a welcome message for the user, including the Duke logo.
return layer("Hello! I'm \n" + LOGO + "What can I do for you?");
* Generates a farewell message for the user.
return layer("Bye. Hope to see you again soon!");
* Executes the specified input command and returns the result.
* If the input is "bye", returns the farewell message. Otherwise, processes the input with the parser.
* @return The result of executing the input command.

assertEquals("[D][ ] Find Bill(by: 01/01/2020 1900hrs)", new Deadlines("Find Bill", dateTime).toString());
